An **aklys** is a type of [weapon](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It uses the [club](/wiki/Club "Club") skill, and appears as a **thonged club** when [unidentified](/wiki/Identification "Identification"). It is made of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Origin](#Origin)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [6.2 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [6.3 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)

- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [8 References](#References)

## Generation

The aklys makes up about 0.8% of randomly generated weapons (on the ground, as [death drops](/wiki/Death_drop "Death drop"), and in [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop")).

[Humanoid](/wiki/Humanoid "Humanoid") monsters that can wield weapons and have a weapon attack, but no default [monster starting inventory](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory"), can generate with an aklys unless they are created on the [Rogue level](/wiki/Rogue_level "Rogue level"): the base odds are 1⁄14 for normal monsters, 1⁄12 for a monster that is a [lord](/wiki/M2_LORD "M2 LORD") or [nasty](/wiki/Nasty "Nasty"), 1⁄10 for a monster that is an [overlord](/wiki/M2_PRINCE "M2 PRINCE") or both a lord and nasty, and 1⁄8 for a monster that is both nasty and an overlord.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

## Description

An aklys has the same hit dice versus small and large [monsters](/wiki/Monster "Monster") as a club, but is much lighter. Unlike a club, it can also be tethered and used as a [projectile](/wiki/Projectile "Projectile") weapon, and gains a +2 [to-hit](/wiki/To-hit "To-hit") bonus when [thrown](/wiki/Thrown "Thrown").[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) The aklys remains tethered while wielded: a wielded aklys has a maximum thrown range of 4 [squares](/wiki/Square "Square") and behaves slightly like [Mjollnir](/wiki/Mjollnir "Mjollnir"), returning 99⁄100 of the time when thrown.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)[\[5\]](#cite_note-5) A [player](/wiki/Player "Player") character will catch a tethered aklys 99⁄100 of the time if not [impaired](/wiki/Impaired "Impaired") in some manner (e.g. [blind](/wiki/Blind "Blind"), [stunned](/wiki/Stunned "Stunned"), [confused](/wiki/Confused "Confused"), etc.), and the remaining 1⁄100 of the time it will either land at their feet or hit them in the arm.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)

## Strategy

Compared to a stack of a dozen daggers, one aklys is far lighter and can be reused until it fails to return—even then, in most cases it can be easily retrieved. The aklys also has higher base damage than a dagger; although daggers can be multishot to do more damage, it is usually easier to find a blessed or enchanted aklys in the Mines, compared to procuring a stack of above-average daggers.

On the other hand, the aklys has a limited range and must be wielded before throwing in order to return: this means one action will be used switching to it before firing, and switching back if the target gets close uses up another action. There is also the small chance of it backfiring and striking the character upon returning, though this does not deal much damage - a far more pressing concern is having the wielded aklys cursed, which prevents throwing *and* switching to a different weapon until it is uncursed.

For [Cavemen](/wiki/Cavemen "Cavemen") and [Priests](/wiki/Priest "Priest"), who cannot multishot daggers but can achieve Expert in club, an aklys is a worthwhile primary weapon for melee and ranged attacks alike—while other roles can utilize the aklys this way, they may also opt to use it as a backup ranged weapon when their primary projectile runs out, which in turn lets them save capacity by carrying fewer projectiles than they would otherwise. The aklys is also excellent against [sea monsters](/wiki/Sea_monster "Sea monster"), since it lets characters stay out of melee range, yet you don't have to worry about retrieving your [projectiles](/wiki/Projectiles "Projectiles") from water afterwards. While [polearms](/wiki/Polearm "Polearm") have higher base damage, they are also much heavier and [two-handed](/wiki/Two-handed "Two-handed").

The aklys is often associated with [gnomes](/wiki/Gnomes "Gnomes"), who qualify for the generation cases discussed above and generate in large numbers in the [early game](/wiki/Early_game "Early game"), specifically in the [Gnomish Mines](/wiki/Gnomish_Mines "Gnomish Mines"). Those attempting a gnomish [racial ascension](/wiki/Unofficial_conduct#Racial "Unofficial conduct") often consider the aklys as the only acceptable melee weapon for this reason.

## History

The aklys first appears in [NetHack 1.3d](/wiki/NetHack_1.3d "NetHack 1.3d"), where it has a relative probability of 1⁄99 to generate and weighs three units, making it the second-heaviest item after the [two handed sword](/wiki/Two_handed_sword "Two handed sword") (which weighs four units).[\[8\]](#cite_note-8) This "rarity" is shared with many objects, including even the [katana](/wiki/Katana "Katana"), and remains unchanged until [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3").

The ability to throw a wielded aklys and have it return to the player's hand is introduced in [NetHack 3.6.1](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.1 "NetHack 3.6.1").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Aklys](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aklys "wikipedia:Aklys")***

The word "aklys" comes from the Latin *aclys* and Greek *agkulis*, and refers to a Roman missile weapon; it is uncertain whether the "proper" plural would be "aklyses" (going by general English rules) or "aclydes" (by Latin rules)—in any case, the aklys [does not stack](/wiki/Stackable "Stackable"), so it is unclear what *NetHack* would use.

There are two types of aklys: one resembles a [javelin](/wiki/Javelin "Javelin") and measured approximately 2 m (79 in) in length, and was thrown using a leather strap (or *amentum*); the word was translated as "javelin" in English translations of Roman works such as the *Aeneid*. The second type of aklys is a small spiked mace or club attached to the wielder's arm by a strap of adjustable length, ensuring the weapon could be retrieved after it was thrown.

The aklys also appears in various fantasy games such as *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, where it is found in *[Dragon Magazine](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dragon_\(magazine\) "wikipedia:Dragon (magazine)")* Vol. 7, No. 2, as well as the 1985 *Unearthed Arcana* supplement by co-creator Gary Gygax. This aklys is directly patterned after the second, blunt type of aklys and serves as the basis for the weapon and its hit dice in *NetHack*.

## Variants

Some variants based on 3.4.3 adopt the updated behavior for the aklys introduced in later versions of vanilla *NetHack*, while others leave it unchanged.

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), characters can throw a wielded aklys and have it return as in vanilla *NetHack*.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"), characters and other monsters can [apply](/wiki/Apply "Apply") an aklys to [pound](/wiki/Pound "Pound") targets as with a polearm.

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), characters can throw a wielded aklys and have it return as in vanilla *NetHack*.

## Encyclopedia entry

A short studded or spiked club attached to a cord allowing it to be drawn back to the wielder after having been thrown. It should not be confused with the atlatl, which is a device used to throw spears for longer distances.
